examples.en: Long time no see!
examples.ja: 久しぶりですね！

examples.en: Beer after being sober for so long was so good it brought me to tears.
examples.ja: 久しぶりのビールは、なみだが出るほどおいしかった。

examples.en: I was told "long time no see" by a person that I had never met before.
examples.ja: 久しぶり！とあったことのない人にいわれた。

meaning_mnemonic: This is kind of a "set phrase" in Japanese, though we're going to treat it like a vocab word here (because it's so common and useful!). You know that <kanji>久</kanji> means "long time" - so now let's pay attention to the kana: しぶり. Just imagine that <reading>she buri</reading>ed you alive, then a few days later came back to dig you up. The first thing she says is "<vocabulary>LONG TIME NO SEE!</vocabulary>"
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned 久しい. It's the same one!

examples.en: "What do you do every day?" "I practice impersonations all day, every day."
examples.ja: 「いつも何してるの？」「毎日一日中物真似の練習をしてるよ。」

meaning_mnemonic:
真似 is "impersonation." Actually, this word is too. It's also <vocabulary>impersonation</vocabulary>.

物真似 is very similar to 真似, but can be used in slightly different contexts. 真似 is used for general acts of mimicry or imitation, and can also be used to refer to the way someone does something. On the other hand, while 物真似 also describes acts of mimicry and imitation, it's additionally used in performance or entertainment contexts to refer to people who do impersonation acts.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 物 plus 真似 put together.

examples.en: The plural of sheep is sheep.
examples.ja: Sheepの複数形はsheepです。

examples.en: My friend said, "You don't even know the plural of this word?" and laughed at me, and I was very hurt.
examples.ja: 「この単語の複数形も知らないの？」って友達に笑われて、とても傷つきました。

examples.en: In Japanese you don’t need to change things to the plural form as often as in English.
examples.ja: 日本語では英語に比べて単語を複数形にすることは少ないです。

meaning_mnemonic: If 複数 is <kanji>multiple</kanji>, and 形 is <kanji>shape</kanji>, then when something is in a "multiple shape," it has more than one version of itself. It's the <vocabulary>plural</vocabulary>, or the <vocabulary>plural form</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 複数 as well.

examples.en: I have a kind of telephone phobia and my heart starts beating very fast whenever I talk on the phone.
examples.ja: 電話恐怖症みたいなのがあって、電話で話をする時に心臓がバクバクするんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>internal organs</kanji> is the <vocabulary>heart</vocabulary>, of course.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My grandfather died of inflammation of the lungs.
examples.ja: 私の祖父は肺臓炎で亡くなりました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>lung</kanji> <kanji>internal organ</kanji> is the <vocabulary>lung</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: They take the internal organs out of deer in my neighbor’s garage.
examples.ja: ご近所さんのガレージで鹿の内臓を取り出すんです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Inside</kanji> <kanji>internal organs</kanji> are your <vocabulary>internal organs</vocabulary>, though you'd think the second kanji would give a hint to that without the 内.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: "Dad, Fugu and I are getting married and moving to Japan." "Not while I’m alive, you won’t."
examples.ja: 「パパ、フグと私、結婚して日本に引っ越すつもりよ。」「俺の目の黒いうちはそんなことはさせないぞ。」

meaning_mnemonic: 越す is "to go beyond." Now you're going beyond your home and <kanji>pull</kanji>ing everything with you to go to another home. You are trying <vocabulary>to move</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>to move homes</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 引く and 越す put together. Careful of that っ.

examples.en: I always wave my hand to say hi whenever I pass other bikers.
examples.ja: 他の自転車走者を追い越す時、いつも挨拶代わりに手を振ります。

meaning_mnemonic: 越す means "to go beyond." 追 is <kanji>follow</kanji>. If you are following someone, and then you go beyond them, you have overtaken them. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to overtake</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to surpass</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 追う and 越す put together into one. You can overtake this word now that you know that.

examples.en: My grandparents still see their pediatrician.
examples.ja: 私の祖父母はまだ小児科医にかかっています。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 祖父 is grandfather and 祖母 is grandmother. This is both combined. Is it some hybrid grandmapa monster you've created in your lab? Hardly, it just refers to your <vocabulary>grandparents</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 祖父 and 祖母, which are exceptional readings on their own, so you'll need them in order to be able to read this one too.

examples.en: If a dog’s owner had chickenpox, could the dog get it too?
examples.ja: もし犬の飼い主が水疱瘡になったら、その犬も水疱瘡になる可能性はあるんでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that to 飼う is "to keep a pet." If you're the <kanji>master</kanji> that is <kanji>keeping a pet</kanji> (飼う), then you are the <vocabulary>pet owner</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings for both. You'll need to remember the words 飼う and 主 to be able to remember the reading of this word.

examples.en: I might have scratched my contact lens.
examples.ja: コンタクトレンズを傷つけちゃったかも。

examples.en: We may also be hurting people without knowing it.
examples.ja: 私たちも知らないうちに人を傷つけているかもしれません。

examples.en: Who the heck damaged my Mercedes with an iron bar?! They'll pay for this!
examples.ja: 誰だよ？俺のベンツに鉄棒で傷つけやがったのは？！見つけたらただじゃおかねえぞ！

meaning_mnemonic: You つける (attach) a <kanji>wound</kanji> to someone or something. In other words, this means <vocabulary>to hurt someone</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to scratch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to damage</vocabulary> something.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 傷. If you remember the reading for that you got this too.

examples.en: For me, disposable pocket warmers are indispensable in winter.
examples.ja: 私にとって、使い捨てカイロは冬には無くてはならないものです。

meaning_mnemonic: After you <kanji>use</kanji> it you <kanji>throw away</kanji> it, making whatever it is you used a <vocabulary>disposable</vocabulary> item.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 使う and 捨てる, combined into one.

examples.en: I threw my alarm clock away when it went off at six this morning.
examples.ja: 今朝、六時に目覚ましがなった時に、その時計を投げ捨ててしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>throw</kanji> and <kanji>throw away</kanji> something. That's why this means <vocabulary>to throw away</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 投げる and 捨てる, combined into one garbage inducing dump of a word.

examples.en: I didn’t have enough time to load rounds into the shotgun.
examples.ja: ショットガンに弾を込める時間がなかったんだ。

examples.en: Put more emotion in your performance! Are you really a professional theatrical actor?
examples.ja: もっと気持ちを込めて演技しろよ！それでもプロの劇団員か？

meaning_mnemonic: You know the kanji 込 means <kanji>into</kanji>. This verb is transitive, meaning you are doing the action. If you “do something into something” you are putting it into that thing. So this means <vocabulary>to put in</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to load something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Lucky for you, the reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here. In case you need a hand with the okurigana, here’s a mnemonic for you:

You always try <vocabulary>to put in</vocabulary> your emotions into the <reading>mail</reading> (める) you send. You don't just load your mail with words, but also with emotions, to make it truly heartfelt mail.

examples.en: I forgot to apply for the JLPT exam.
examples.ja: JLPTのテストに申し込むのを忘れてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
I must <kanji>say humbly</kanji> that I want to get <kanji>into</kanji> this position, so I'm planning <vocabulary>to apply</vocabulary> for it and <vocabulary>to submit an application</vocabulary>.

申し込む isn't just about applying, though. It's about officially communicating desires, whether you want <vocabulary>to propose</vocabulary> marriage, challenge someone to a game of tennis, or even offer a donation to a good cause.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the word 申す and the kanji 込, stuck together... humbly.

examples.en: He hooked up my PlayStation to his TV before leaving our house to commit suicide by jumping in front of a train. Do you think it means something?
examples.ja: あいつ、飛び込み自殺をするために家を出る前、俺のプレイステーションをあいつのテレビに繋いだんだよな。何か意味があったのかな？

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>fly</kanji> <kanji>into</kanji> something and "commit suicide" (自殺) is <vocabulary>suicide by train</vocabulary>. Unfortunately, this is a term you should probably be familiar with because it comes up from time to time on the news and around train stations. (Hopefully someday it will no longer be a term you need to know and we can remove it forever.)
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 飛ぶ, 込, and 自殺. Combine them together to read this entire word.

examples.en: You better hurry up and fill out an application. The office will close in ten minutes.
examples.ja: 急いで申込書に書き込んだ方がいいよ。あと十分で事務所は閉まっちゃうんだから。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that 書く is "to write" and the kanji 込 is into, so this means <vocabulary>to write in</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to fill out</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to jot down</vocabulary>.

書き込む focuses more on the physical action of writing than 書く on its own. This is because 込む stresses that you’re putting words INTO some space, either on paper or on computer.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the word 書く and the kanji 込 combined into one.

examples.en: I can't go into the middle of a crowd of people because I'm scared.
examples.ja: 怖くて人込みの中に行けません。

examples.en: When I walk inside Shinjuku Station, I always get frustrated with the crowds of people.
examples.ja: 新宿駅構内を歩く時は、人込みでいつもイライラする。

examples.en: After saying so, the man vanished into the crowd.
examples.ja: 男はそう言うと、人込みにまぎれて消えてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
When a <kanji>person</kanji> goes <kanji>into</kanji> a place (then another person goes into the place, and then another person and another person), that place eventually gets filled with a <vocabulary>crowd of people</vocabulary>.

Note that this word is more commonly written 人混み.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the word 人 and the kanji 込. Just keep in mind that the こ changes to ご and you'll be fine.

examples.en: Couldn’t you find some way to remove this stain?
examples.ja: この染みなんとか取れないかなあ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of 染. A dye would seem like the right answer, but what else is a dye? If you get it on you when you don't want to get it on you, it becomes a <vocabulary>stain</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is unlike what you learned with this kanji before. Just think about how you have this <vocabulary>stain</vocabulary> on your shirt, all because you were trying to dye some <reading>shee</reading>p (し) and they didn't like it. So now you have a big dye and sheep poo stain. How were you supposed to know sheep don't like being dyed?!

examples.en: I’m worried that our kids will be tainted by this bad environment.
examples.ja: 子供たちがこの悪い環境に染まってしまうことを心配してるのよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If 染める is "to dye," then this is <vocabulary>to be dyed</vocabulary>. You aren't doing the dyeing, because you know that if you did it you would have done things right, unlike the other person who dyed your hair. This person <reading>marr</reading>ed (まる) it up really bad.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 染める.

examples.en: We are out of clean bibs. Our baby boy got them all dirty.
examples.ja: 綺麗なスタイが無くなっちゃった。うちの赤ちゃんが全部汚しちゃって。

examples.en: He is a cunning man who never dirties his hands.
examples.ja: アイツは自分では決して手を汚さない、ずるい男だ。

examples.en: Terrible!!! I cannot tolerate it. It feels like a sacred place has been defiled.
examples.ja: ひどい！許せません。神聖な場所を汚された気分です。

meaning_mnemonic: 汚れる is "to get dirty." This is when you make something dirty, aka "<vocabulary>to make dirty</vocabulary>." You know that this is the version where you make things dirty yourself because when you make someone dirty with all that poop you're flinging, they <reading>sue</reading> (す) you immediately. This happens a lot.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading comes from 汚れる, so if you know that you can read this.

Note that the reading よごす  is generally used for making things physically dirty, whereas けがす means making someone or something impure in a figurative way.

examples.en: I sent her an explanation email and I hope she can understand.
examples.ja: 分かってもらえることを願って、言い訳を書いたEメールを送りました。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>say</kanji> a <kanji>reason</kanji> for your actions, but really it's just an <vocabulary>excuse</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 言う and 訳 combined.

examples.en: I managed to cram all my clothes into my suitcase.
examples.ja: なんとか洋服を全部スーツケースに詰め込めました。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that 詰める is "to stuff in" and the kanji 込 is <kanji>into</kanji>. When you’re stuffing something into something else, you are going <vocabulary>to stuff</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cram</vocabulary> it in.

Just as in English, this word can also be used in a figurative sense, like cramming knowledge into your head.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. If you remember your kanji readings, you'll be fine here.

examples.en: I saw a box on the counter that had "tips welcome" written on it.
examples.ja: カウンターの上に「チップ大歓迎」と書かれた箱がありましたよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
It's my <kanji>delight</kanji> to <kanji>welcome</kanji> you, so I give you a big, warm <vocabulary>welcome</vocabulary>.

歓迎 is a relatively formal word that refers to warmly accepting someone in, like <vocabulary>welcoming</vocabulary> someone who's arrived somewhere or joined a group.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I don’t like people whose blood type is B.
examples.ja: 私は血液型がB型の人が苦手です。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>blood</kanji> <kanji>fluid</kanji> <kanji>type</kanji> is your <vocabulary>blood type</vocabulary>. This is a very important thing to know in Japan for some reason.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, at least the 血液 part. The 型 uses the kun'yomi reading, probably because it's an add-on word.

examples.en: I’m not interested in building personal relationships with customers.
examples.ja: 俺は顧客と個人的に仲良くなることには興味がないんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: 興味 is <kanji>interest</kanji> in something. If you do not have (がない) that interest, then you have <vocabulary>no interest</vocabulary> or you're <vocabulary>not interested</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You learned that the word 興味 uses the on'yomi readings for both kanji, so all you have to do is add が + ない and you've got a new expression!

examples.en: I agree that it’s a game we must win by any means necessary.
examples.ja: それがどんな汚い手を使ってでも勝たなきゃいけない試合だってことには賛成するよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The 賛成 portion means "agreement", "approval", or "support", so the verb version would also be <vocabulary>to agree</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to approve</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to support</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You’ve got the wrong idea. She’s my older sister.
examples.ja: 君は誤解しているよ。あれは俺の姉貴だよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mistake</kanji> in what you <kanji>solve</kanji>... wow, sorry, I thought I was supposed to solve this, not that. What a terrible <vocabulary>misunderstanding</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: For now, all you have to do is find typos.
examples.ja: とりあえず今は誤字脱字を見つけてくれればそれでいいから。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mistake</kanji> in <kanji>letter</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>typo</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Misuse of medicine can be fatal.
examples.ja: 薬の誤用は命に関わることがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mistake</kanji> in <kanji>use</kanji> is a <vocabulary>misuse</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I was wrong in thinking that she would speak decent English.
examples.ja: 彼女は英語がペラペラだと思ったが、とんだ誤算だった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mistake</kanji> in what you <kanji>calculate</kanji> is a <vocabulary>miscalculation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Life is as precious as bacon.
examples.ja: 命ってのはベーコンと同じくらい貴いものなんだよ。

examples.en: He was born into the nobility.
examples.ja: 彼は生まれながらにして貴い身分を持っていた。

examples.en: His face is so noble and divine that I hesitate to approach.
examples.ja: お顔が貴すぎて、近づくのもためらってしまう。

examples.en: The king was moved by the young man's noble act.
examples.ja: 王はその若者の貴い行いに感動しました。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. This adjective describes things that are <kanji>valuable</kanji> in a way that transcends monetary worth, so it means <vocabulary>noble</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>invaluable</vocabulary>.

While 尊い is used for things you honor from the heart, 貴い leans toward a dignified, noble kind of value — the kind tied to high status or social rank. Because of that, you may encounter 貴い in stories about historical class systems or old social hierarchies. It doesn't appear as commonly as 尊い in modern Japanese, but you may still see it in descriptions of someone's noble presence or the sense of dignity they give off.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. This has the same reading as 尊い (revered, noble), so if you remember that, you can read 貴い too! In case you forgot, here's a mnemonic to help you: 

How can you tell if someone comes from a <vocabulary>noble</vocabulary> background? Just check their <reading>toe toe</reading> (とうと). Most noble families are pretty inbred, so a lot of their members will have a big toe (the long とう) with another small toe growing out of it (short と). This is a common birth defect among inbred aristocrats. Of course, from their point of view, it's <vocabulary>invaluable</vocabulary> proof of how noble and superior they are.

examples.en: Your older brother is a really cool guy, but mine is not.
examples.ja: お前の兄貴はイケてるけど、俺の兄貴はダサイからな。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>older brother</kanji> is <kanji>valuable</kanji> to you. But, no matter how valuable he is to you, he's still just your <vocabulary>older brother</vocabulary>. 

P.S. You'll often see some gangstah thug call a higher ranking gangstah thug (one that acts like an older brother to all the other gangstah thugs) this. It's like family within the gang.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 兄 on its own plus the reading for 貴. ANIKIIIII.

examples.en: Hey, you keep your mouth shut!
examples.ja: おい、貴様はだまっていろ！

examples.en: What!? Why are you here!?
examples.ja: なぬっ、なぜ貴様がここにいる！？

examples.en: Fine, let's see what you can do.
examples.ja: いいだろう、貴様の実力を見せてもらおうか。

examples.en: I couldn't sleep a wink because YOU were so damn noisy.
examples.ja: 貴様がうるさかったせいで、昨日全然寝れなかったじゃねぇか。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>valuable</kanji> <kanji>formal name ender</kanji>. It's like saying "the valuable great you"... or something. Anyways, this means <vocabulary>you</vocabulary>, but it isn't as nice as it sounds.

貴様 used to be a polite way to say "you," but in modern Japanese it's almost always a strong insult, roughly like saying <vocabulary>you bastard</vocabulary>. The tone is dramatic, so you'll hear it from anime villains, but not usually in real conversation unless someone's joking around and pretending to be Vegeta from Dragon Ball.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the reading you learned with 貴 plus the vocab reading for 様.

examples.en: In that country, the nobles controlled politics.
examples.ja: その国では、貴族たちが政治を左右していた。

examples.en: Everyone was shocked when I told them I have noble blood.
examples.ja: 俺が貴族の血を引いているって言ったら、みんなビックリしてたよ。

examples.en: Ah, if only I had been born into a noble family, I might have been able to talk to her.
examples.ja: ああ、もし私が貴族の家柄に生まれていたら、彼女と話をすることも可能だったかもしれないのに。

examples.en: A single person who can do whatever they want is basically living like an aristocrat, right? That's why we call them a "single aristocrat."
examples.ja: 自由にいろんなことができる独身者の生活って、まるで貴族みたいでしょ？だから「独身貴族」って言われるんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
People of a <kanji>valuable</kanji> <kanji>tribe</kanji> are part of <vocabulary>the nobility</vocabulary>. Unlike our tribes, they are valuable.

貴族 refers to a noble or <vocabulary>aristocrat</vocabulary> in old social systems, so you mostly see it in history books or fantasy settings. In modern Japanese, people sometimes use it jokingly when a person does something very luxurious or indulgent — as if they're living like an aristocrat for a moment.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I haven’t given up yet.
examples.ja: 私はまだ降参していません。

meaning_mnemonic: I am going to <kanji>descend</kanji> my <kanji>participat</kanji>ion in this conflict. I am going to descend all my weapons to the ground. I am going to <vocabulary>surrender</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: "This beef bowl is my treat." "Oh, thank you. I’ll take you up on that."
examples.ja: 「この牛丼は、私のおごりね。」「わあ、ありがとう。じゃあ、お言葉に甘えます。」

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>cow</kanji> <kanji>rice bowl</kanji> is a bowl of rice covered in beef, making it a <vocabulary>beef bowl</vocabulary>. Go get some Yoshinoya.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the same readings that you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I'd like to buy some tableware in America, like Japanese rice bowls, but I can't find the right size!
examples.ja: アメリカで日本の丼みたいな食器を買いたいんですが、ちょうどいいサイズのがないんですよね〜。

examples.en: Hey, there was dried-up natto in that rice bowl!

examples.en: You're eating a crab bowl in the morning? You're a real morning person, aren't you?
examples.ja: 朝から蟹丼なんて食べてるの？あんたって、本当に朝型人間ね。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

To be exact, 丼 refers to a chinaware bowl that's bigger and sturdier than your ordinary <vocabulary>rice bowl</vocabulary>. It's often used for one-bowl dishes like katsudon, gyūdon, poke, but also noodle soups like ramen!
reading_mnemonic:
You learned the どん reading for this kanji, and this reading is just an extension of that, coming out to どんぶり. This change might be a little tricky to remember, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

<vocabulary>Rice bowl</vocabulary>s keep disappearing, and everyone's terrified. Who's behind it? <reading>Don Brie</reading> (どんぶり), the feared cheese-loving mafia boss. He wants those rice bowls to eat all his brie out of, because I guess plates aren't good enough. That's why they call him Don Brie.

examples.en: "I’m sorry I’m late. I was sick and threw up this morning." "It’s okay. Better late than never."
examples.ja: 「遅れてごめんなさい。朝、少し気分が悪くて吐いてしまって。」「大丈夫だよ。遅れても来ないよりはましだよ。」

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>throw up</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to throw up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to puke</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to spit</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is from the reading you learned with the kanji. HA HA HA! Barf.

examples.en: After winning the lottery, that dude was on a high for weeks.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: 

Some <vocabulary>dude</vocabulary>... he did it two times. <reading>Yah, two</reading> (やつ) times.

This can seem kind of derogatory, if you say it the wrong way. But as long as you're duding to your dude friends and not your no-dude boss, you should be a-okay to dude-bro it up!

examples.en: Don’t lose your cool. Don’t worry. We are still slaves now, but things will work out.

reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shrink</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to shrink</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Jesus couldn't cause the monster <vocabulary>to shrink</vocabulary>. He had to transform into <reading>cheese jesus</reading> (ちぢ), a more powerful version of himself, in order to shrink the monster down to size.

examples.en: I’m looking for nice curtains that will suit our 100 centimeter by 160 centimeter window.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

examples.en: I want to write compositions using vertical style writing.
examples.ja: 文章を縦書にしたいんです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Vertical</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is <vocabulary>vertical writing</vocabulary>. That's when you see Japanese and it's written top to bottom instead of sideways.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the reading you learned with the kanji 縦 and かき (changes to がき), though the き gets smushed inside the kanji, because it wants to be confusing like that.

examples.en: Can you help me measure the vertical and horizontal lengths of this wall?

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Vertical</kanji> and <kanji>side</kanji> (horizontal). That means you have the <vocabulary>length and width</vocabulary> and the <vocabulary>vertical and horizontal</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that usually uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Note however, that there is a less-common on'yomi reading,  じゅうおう, which is used in some idioms. It's good to know this reading exists, but you probably won't come across it very often.

examples.en: I'm still with my husband for purely financial reasons.
examples.ja: 純粋に金銭的な理由だけで、夫とまだ一緒にいるんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Pure</kanji> plus 粋, which you might remember as "stylish" but which can mean <kanji>pure</kanji> as well. Wow, that's double the purity for this word. No wonder it also means <vocabulary>pure</vocabulary>! 

純粋 is usually for pure-hearted people or feelings, like 純粋な心 (a pure heart) or 純粋な気持ち (pure feelings). You can also say 純粋な疑問 — for <vocabulary>genuine</vocabulary> doubt or innocent wondering that just popped into your head, purely out of curiosity, with no hidden motives.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The way our teacher wears her kimono is so stylish and classy, isn't it? I really admire it.
examples.ja: 先生の着物の着こなしって、本当に粋ですよね。めっちゃ憧れます。

examples.en: Oh, that's a classy way to live. And no, that's not a pun!
examples.ja: へー、それは粋な生き方だね。って、ダジャレじゃないよ！

examples.en: Thanks to the owner's thoughtful gesture, we got free dessert.

examples.en: What annoys me is that he thinks he's having these cool, witty conversations. He might think he's pulling it off, but he always falls flat.
examples.ja: アイツ、自分で粋な会話をしてるって思ってるところがムカツクんだよね。粋にキメてるつもりかもしれないけど、いつもダダすべりだっつーの。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

粋 means <vocabulary>stylish</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>chic</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>tasteful</vocabulary>, but with a nuance of understated elegance or refined coolness. For example, arranging something behind the scenes so things go beautifully might be regarded as 粋 — a <vocabulary>classy</vocabulary> gesture done with style!
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You are <vocabulary>stylish</vocabulary>. Since you're stylish, you avoid <reading>icky</reading> (いき) clothing at all costs. You won't even be seen in the same room, that's how stylish you are.

To remember this, just think how you are using a magnet to find this <reading>shack</reading> (しゃく) full of other magnets. It pulls you towards the shack, and when you find it and open it, all the magnets fly out and crush you because of magnety reasons.

reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading for 場 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

Do <vocabulary>magnetic field</vocabulary>s say "<reading>baa</reading>" (ば)? No, but some studies suggest that sheep like to align themselves to Earth's magnetic field lines when they're standing around. Just a bit of weird baa-rnyard trivia for you!

This person is the <vocabulary>wirepuller</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mastermind</vocabulary> of the situation. Like the Wizard of Oz, or something.

examples.en: My family gathers in front of our family Buddhist altar to pray to Buddha every morning.

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>worship</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to worship</vocabulary>.

拝む generally means <vocabulary>to pray to</vocabulary> a deity, spirit, or revered object while assuming a worshipping position, such as bowing or clasping one's hands together in prayer. Additionally, 拝む can also mean <vocabulary>to see</vocabulary> with a sense of respect and reverence.
reading_mnemonic: You have <vocabulary>to worship</vocabulary> the <reading>ogre</reading> (おが), because if you don't it'll eat your face off.

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>worship</kanji> only the things you <kanji>see</kanji>. So, in order to see if something is worth worshiping, you'll go <vocabulary>to have a look at</vocabulary> that thing.

And just so you know, this is a very formal word used when you're trying to be polite. So keep that in mind, please!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The company director’s estimated annual salary is around 50 million yen.

You’re doing a bit of <kanji>infer</kanji>ring while you <kanji>determine</kanji> something, which means you’re not 100% sure, making this an <vocabulary>estimation</vocabulary>.

推定 refers to an estimation that’s generally based on some evidence or reasoning. You’ll often find this used in statistical or scientific contexts, where it refers to an educated guess or estimation based on available data.

examples.en: He recommended this show to me, but I don’t really like watching anime.
examples.ja: この番組を彼に薦められたんだけど、アニメを観るのはあまり好きじゃないんだよね。

examples.en: Koichi said the crab cakes were delicious and recommended them; when I tried them they tasted terrible.
examples.ja: コウイチが美味しいと薦めてきたクラブケーキを食べてみたらすごく不味かった。

examples.en: I recommend mystery fans go see this movie.
examples.ja: ミステリーファンにはこの映画を見ることを薦めます。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>recommend</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to recommend</vocabulary>. This word is often used in a positive context for recommending things, actions, and people by implying or pointing out their charms, merits, or both.

Although 薦める and 勧める are similar, there are subtle differences between the two. 勧める is often used to suggest that someone perform a specific action, often as friendly advice or encouragement. It can also be used when offering something, such as a drink. On the other hand, 薦める is used to recommend a person or thing as suitable for a particular situation, with a focus on endorsing the subject rather than a specific action.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as 勧める, since they mean almost the same thing.

examples.en: Who demonstrated the most leadership in solving the problem?

meaning_mnemonic:
You cause the <kanji>departure</kanji> of something in you (to the outside), then <kanji>brandish</kanji> it for all to see. You're sending it out to show everyone. That's why this means <vocabulary>to exhibit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to demonstrate</vocabulary>.

発揮する means <vocabulary>to bring out</vocabulary> one's abilities, strengths, or qualities in a visible or effective way. It's often used when someone performs well under pressure or maximizes their potential in a given situation.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The はつ becomes はっ, though.

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>run alongside</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to run alongside</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Imagine yourself on a path designed <vocabulary>to run alongside</vocabulary> an endless array of <reading>so</reading>ap (そ) bars. As you walk alongside the soap bars, you enjoy their delightful scents. It's a "scent-sational" promenade with soap bars that leaves you feeling squeaky clean!

examples.en: Music is a source of power in my daily life.
examples.ja: 音楽が私の日々の生活のパワーの源です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>origin</kanji> is the <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary>, but it also refers to the <vocabulary>ground spring</vocabulary>s, where the origin of water comes from.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Think of how this <vocabulary>ground spring</vocabulary> is everyone's (皆) origin (元). Everyone can use it, it's the 皆元!

examples.en: Why is the fake name for prostitutes, hostesses, and geisha called a "Genji name?"
examples.ja: どうして娼婦やホステス、キャバ嬢、芸者さんなどが使う偽名を「源氏名」って言うんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>family name</kanji> is the original dude. The original dude comes from the original and first novel ever written, the Tale of <kanji>Genji</kanji>. These kanji represent <vocabulary>Genji</vocabulary>, good ol' Genji. Perhaps hopping over to the reading will help you to know the meaning of this kanji.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When I go out, I turn off all the power by unplugging everything from the electrical sockets.
examples.ja: 出かける時は、完全に電源を切るために全部のコンセントを抜きます。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>origin</kanji> is where the electricity comes from. It is the <vocabulary>power source</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m worried about my friends who live close to the epicenter.
examples.ja: 震源地に近いところに住んでる友達が心配だよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>earthquake</kanji> <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>ground</kanji> is where the earthquake started from. It is the <vocabulary>epicenter</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I started working at a library ever since my daughter got into primary school.
examples.ja: 娘が小学校に上がったので、私は図書館に勤め始めました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>work</kanji> which means this verb has something to do with working. It's not straight up "to work," instead it's "<vocabulary>to work for</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>to be employed at</vocabulary>."
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the other word that means "to work as" (務める). Remember this and you'll be able to remember the reading for this word too.

examples.en: Commuting can eat up a lot of time, so I prefer to live near my office.
examples.ja: 通勤は時間を浪費するので、私は職場の近くに住む方がいいですね。

meaning_mnemonic:
The things you <kanji>pass through</kanji> on your way to <kanji>work</kanji> are the things you see and run into during your <vocabulary>commute</vocabulary>.

Note that you can only use this word for commuting to work. You don’t use it to go to school unless you work at a school or something!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I won’t be able to work full-time for now until my child gets a little older.
examples.ja: 子どもがもうちょっと大きくなるまでは、常勤でのお仕事はちょっと無理かな。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Normal</kanji> <kanji>work</kanji> is work you do all day long, 8-hours a day, 5 days a week. That is <vocabulary>full time employment</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>full time</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Would you like to leave a message?
examples.ja: ご伝言を承りましょうか。

meaning_mnemonic:
Giving <kanji>consent</kanji> to someone is similar to humbly listening to and accepting their words. So this word means <vocabulary>to humbly hear</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to accept</vocabulary>.

承る is a humble version of 聞く. Its past form 承りました is commonly used in professional settings to respectfully acknowledge and accept requests, information, or tasks.
reading_mnemonic: You received (<reading>受けた</reading>) some information. Now, you are going to take that information that you received and then revolve it (<reading>回る</reading>) around in your head to think about it. Hmmm... hmm... Ok, I like what I'm hearing. I am going <vocabulary>to accept</vocabulary> what you said. Thank you.

examples.en: I know it's unreasonable, but I'm still asking you.
examples.ja: 無理を承知でお願いしています。

examples.en: I am sure you are all well aware of this incident, but let me explain again.
examples.ja: この事件に関してはみなさまよくご承知のこととは思いますが、もう一度説明させていただきます。

examples.en: I can’t consent to your marrying my daughter.
examples.ja: わしの娘がお前と結婚することは承知できん。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>consent</kanji> and <kanji>know</kanji> everything that's going on. You <vocabulary>consent</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>know</vocabulary> about all this. You're <vocabulary>aware</vocabulary> of it.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn 知's on'yomi when you learned the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You need someone's <vocabulary>consent</vocabulary> before you give them <reading>chee</reading>se (ち). Cheese has the power to enrapture a person and leave them in a state of total ecstasy, so you better make sure they consent and <vocabulary>know</vocabulary> what's about to happen before you feed them any cheese.

examples.en: I don't have much confidence that I can get approval from the committee.
examples.ja: 委員会から承認を得られる自信はあまりありません。

examples.en: The new project proposal was successfully approved.
examples.ja: 新しいプロジェクト案は無事承認されました。

examples.en: I dropped my seal of approval in a bonfire while roasting baked potatoes.
examples.ja: 焼き芋を焼いているたき火の中に承認印を落としてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: I <kanji>recognize</kanji> your <kanji>consent</kanji>. It is an <vocabulary>approval</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>recognition</vocabulary> of what I'm doing.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: On saying that, Kuroda disappeared into the entertainment district.
examples.ja: 黒田はそう言い残すと、歓楽街へと消えていった。

examples.en: What does the tour of the pleasure quarter include?
examples.ja: 歓楽街のツアーには何が含まれていますか。

examples.en: I have traced the source of the rumour that I work in the pleasure quarter.
examples.ja: 私が歓楽街で働いているという噂の源をつきとめました。

meaning_mnemonic:
You'll find <kanji>delight</kanji> and <kanji>comfort</kanji> in these <kanji>streets</kanji>, because you have entered an <vocabulary>entertainment district</vocabulary>! 

歓楽街 refers to an area in a city where many nightlife entertainment venues, like bars, dance clubs, host or hostess clubs, and sometimes businesses offering sketchy red-light adult services, are clustered together.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m worried that you may ruin your health by working too hard.
examples.ja: 働きすぎてあんたが健康を損なうんじゃないかって、心配してるのよ。

meaning_mnemonic: To do <kanji>loss</kanji> to something means you are doing something to make something have loss. This is <vocabulary>to harm</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to injure</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: In order <vocabulary>to harm</vocabulary> your opponent, you go way overboard. You <reading>soak</reading> (そこ) them in acid. Soaked head to toe. Too far man, too far.

examples.en: I had a loss of $500 in poker.
examples.ja: ポーカーで五百ドル損をした。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>loss</kanji> will give you a <vocabulary>disadvantage</vocabulary>. So, try not to get any losses... or you'll be at a disadvantage.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the kanji, so you aren't at a <vocabulary>disadvantage</vocabulary>... this time.

examples.en: The truck crash damaged the cargo, but it was only minor damage.
examples.ja: トラックの衝突で積荷がダメージを受けたが、小さな損害で済んだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>loss</kanji> comes from <kanji>damage</kanji> done to you. This is <vocabulary>damage</vocabulary>.

This word is usually used as a noun. It can occasionally be turned into verb by adding する, but this is very rare!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I went to a pachinko parlor in the hopes of making a lot of money, but I ended up with a heavy loss instead.
examples.ja: 大儲けするつもりでパチンコに行ったが、結局大損してしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>loss</kanji> is a <vocabulary>heavy loss</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the おお reading of 大 coupled with the on'yomi reading for 損. Just keep in mind that the そん changes to ぞん and you'll be good here.

examples.en: If it turns out that the car is a total loss, many insurance companies will not pay the full repair cost.
examples.ja: 車が全損してしまった場合、修理代は保険で全額支払われないことが多いです。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>loss</kanji> is when you lose it all. It is a <vocabulary>total loss</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The branches were bent by blood red apples.
examples.ja: 枝は真っ赤な林檎でたわんでいた。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this is a word made up of a single kanji and nothing else, you can assume that this word will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading you learned for this kanji happens to be the kun'yomi reading as well. So if you know the kanji you know the reading.

examples.en: Beans, beans the magical fruit, the more you eat, the more you toot, the more you toot, the better you feel, so eat some beans at every meal.
examples.ja: お豆さん、お豆さん、魔法の野菜。たくさん食べれば食べるほど、たくさん屁が出るぷっぷぷぷ。たくさんぷっぷぷ屁が出れば、気持ちが良くなるウッフフフ。だから毎食お豆を食べなさい。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: You want your <vocabulary>beans</vocabulary>, but you're also super lazy, so you call for your mom, yelling: "<reading>MAMEYYYYY</reading>, MAMMMEEYYY!" (まめ).

examples.en: Azuki bean paste is made of azuki beans, but it’s pretty high in sugar.
examples.ja: 餡こは小豆から作られているが、けっこう糖分が高い。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Small</kanji> <kanji>bean</kanji>s refer to a type of bean known as <vocabulary>azuki bean</vocabulary>s. It will help if you've heard of this delicious popular bean, because there's not really anything effective we can do with the meaning mnemonic from this point on. Just know that small beans are azuki beans.
reading_mnemonic: The reading doesn't make sense either. If you know that small beans are <vocabulary>azuki beans</vocabulary>, then you know that this is referring to a thing known as <reading>azuki</reading> (あずき). Other than that, there's not much else to do.

examples.en: Don’t get me wrong. I love Japanese food, but natto is the one thing I just can't eat.
examples.ja: 誤解しないでね。日本料理は大好きなんだけど、納豆だけはどうしても食べられないの。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>supply</kanji> of <kanji>bean</kanji>s is when you take a bunch of beans, mash them up into a supply, and then ferment them all together to make them into <vocabulary>natto</vocabulary> (also known as <vocabulary>fermented soybeans</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is an exceptional one. 豆 is okay, and is the on'yomi reading from the kanji. The 納 part is weird though. Instead of being のう it's なっ. But, if you can remember the meaning of this word, you can just think about how you do <reading>not</reading> (なっとう) want to eat <vocabulary>natto</vocabulary>. At least a lot of people don't want to eat it. It's quite the acquired taste.

examples.en: Don’t leave milk out of the fridge because it goes bad easily.
examples.ja: 牛乳は腐りやすいんだから冷蔵庫の外に出しっ放しにしないでね。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rot</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to rot</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Remember the word 臭い, which means "stinky"? When something rots, it becomes stinky, and all <reading>くさ</reading>い.

examples.en: Stainless steel is supposed to withstand corrosion, isn’t it?
examples.ja: ステンレスは腐食作用への耐久性があるんじゃなかったっけ？

meaning_mnemonic: When something <kanji>rot</kanji>s and <kanji>eat</kanji>s away at something, that is <vocabulary>corrosion</vocabulary>. Not a good thing.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There was a smell of something decomposing in the air.
examples.ja: そこには、何かが腐敗したような臭いがただよっていた。

examples.en: This additive prevents food from rotting.
examples.ja: この添加物により、食品の腐敗が防げます。

examples.en: Many people are tired of the corrupt political ring.
examples.ja: 多くの人々が腐敗した政治組織にうんざりしています。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Rot</kanji> and <kanji>failure</kanji> lead to <vocabulary>decomposition</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rotting</vocabulary>. This word also has the related meaning of  <vocabulary>corruption</vocabulary>, similar to how "rotten" can mean "corrupt" in English.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Her right pinky nail is six meters long.
examples.ja: 彼女の右の小指の爪の長さはなんと六メートルもあります。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though it adds a few more meanings as well, like <vocabulary>nail</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>talon</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hoof</vocabulary> or really any hard thing on the ends of fingers or feet.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I was trying to clip my dog's nails but my mobile phone distracted me.
examples.ja: 犬の爪を爪切りで切ってあげようとしてたんですけど、つい携帯に気を取られちゃいました。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>cut</kanji> your <kanji>claw</kanji> you use a <vocabulary>nail clipper</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned for the kanji 爪 and the word for the reading 切る.

examples.en: I can’t be bothered to cut up the green onion.
examples.ja: 葱を刻むのは面倒くさいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>carve</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to carve</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You don't have a knife for your steak, so you have <vocabulary>to carve</vocabulary> it using the <reading>key za</reading>g (きざ) technique. You take a key and zag it through the steak repeatedly until you're able <vocabulary>to cut up</vocabulary> some zaggy bite-sized pieces.

examples.en: The train schedule is a must-have for commuters.
examples.ja: 通勤・通学者にとって、電車の時刻表は絶対に必要なものです。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you take the <kanji>time</kanji> and <kanji>carve</kanji> it onto a <kanji>surface</kanji>, then you've made a <vocabulary>timetable</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>schedule</vocabulary>.

時刻表 generally refers to a timetable or schedule for transportation, such as trains, buses, or flights.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It’s a serious problem that the number of Japanese children with thyroid abnormalities have been increasing.
examples.ja: 甲状腺異常のある日本の子どもたちの数が増えているのは、深刻な問題です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>deep</kanji> <kanji>carve</kanji> is very <vocabulary>serious</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>grave</vocabulary>. Just imagine getting cut with a sword. If the carve is deep, well, that's serious.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You should wipe your glasses.
examples.ja: 眼鏡を拭いた方がいいですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>eyeball</kanji> <kanji>mirror</kanji> is something that refracts and focuses light into your eyeball in a different way so you can see better. Really, these things are glasses, not eye mirrors, but same sort of things when you get down to it. Just imagine someone wearing mirrors on their eyes, and when you ask them what those are for, they just say they're <vocabulary>glasses</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for 眼 is the same as the vocab 眼. The reading for 鏡 is an exception, totally different. It shares a reading with 金 (gold), though, so think of the mirrors on the person's eyes being made of gold. What nice glasses!

This word can also be read as がんきょう, but usually only on official/written documents. If you're speaking and not reading a government document, you should say めがね!

examples.en: The bakufu slaughtered my family.
examples.ja: 幕府が俺の家族を皆殺しにした。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>government</kanji> behind a <kanji>curtain</kanji> is the <vocabulary>bakufu</vocabulary>. They didn't let anyone know their government secrets so they would hide behind that curtain and keep everything to themselves.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 幕 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you try to peek through the <vocabulary>bakufu</vocabulary>'s curtain you'll only see someone's <reading>back</reading> (ばく). They all huddle together to discuss things so a row of hunched backs is all you'll get out of the shogunate. That's not helpful.

examples.en: That book is extremely rare now.
examples.ja: その本は今では非常に貴重です。

examples.en: Thank you for your valuable opinions.
examples.ja: 貴重なご意見を有難うございます。

examples.en: That experience became a valuable lesson for him.
examples.ja: その体験は彼にとって貴重な学びになった。

examples.en: I don't want to waste any more of my precious time.
examples.ja: これ以上、貴重な時間をムダにしたくないんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something that's <kanji>valuable</kanji> and <kanji>heavy</kanji> is extremely <vocabulary>precious</vocabulary> and probably even more <vocabulary>valuable</vocabulary> than your less heavy things.

貴重 is used especially when something is rare, important, or hard to replace. You can use it for physical things, but you'll see it used to show appreciation for intangible things too, like 貴重なご意見 (your valuable opinion) or 貴重な体験 (a precious experience).
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 重 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Keep things <vocabulary>precious</vocabulary> to you very close, because the evil Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう) will come and steal them away if you don't. She'll take all the <vocabulary>valuable</vocabulary> things you have and destroy them.

examples.en: I’ll send someone to meet you at the station.
examples.ja: 駅まで迎えをよこすよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>welcome</kanji>, so it means a <vocabulary>welcome</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>greeting</vocabulary>, but it's usually used for someone who's coming and <vocabulary>meeting</vocabulary> you!
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: I bought this avocado yesterday and it’s already gone bad.
examples.ja: このアボカド、昨日買ったところなのにもう傷んでるよ。

examples.en: It looks like the box was damaged because I put it in a place where it was exposed to sunlight.
examples.ja: 日の光が当たる所に置いていたせいで、箱が傷んでしまったみたい。

examples.en: Fresh cream spoils easily, so please put it back in the fridge as soon as you finish using it.
examples.ja: 生クリームは傷みやすいから、使ったらすぐに冷蔵庫に閉まってね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>wound</kanji>, and this verb is intransitive, so it means <vocabulary>to be damaged</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to go bad</vocabulary>. After all, fruit with a wound on it is going bad, isn't it?
reading_mnemonic: This shares the same reading as 痛む. The meanings are similar too, so that should be easy to remember, unless your brain was damaged by these mnemonics or something.

examples.en: The answer will be next week or after.
examples.ja: 返事は来週以降になります。

examples.en: Could you call us again on or after August third?
examples.ja: 八月三日以降にもう一度ご連絡していただけますか？

examples.en: My dad forbids me from going out after 9 p.m.
examples.ja: 夜九時以降の外出は父に禁止されているんです。

meaning_mnemonic: Everything that happened <kanji>since</kanji> you <kanji>descend</kanji>ed some stairs, is <vocabulary>hereafter</vocabulary>. It's all <vocabulary>after</vocabulary> the stairs thing you did, <vocabulary>since</vocabulary> you did it already.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It's been a couple years since I started saying, "I want to lose weight."
examples.ja: 「痩せたい」と、言い始めてから二年が経ちます。

examples.en: Most stray dogs in my village are skinny.
examples.ja: 私の村にいる野良犬のほとんどは痩せていますよ。

examples.en: When it gets silent and awkward during conversations, I make it a rule to just say, "Have you lost weight lately?"
examples.ja: 会話が途切れて気まずくなった時は、とりあえず「最近、痩せた？」と言うことにしている。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>thin</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to get thin</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you want <vocabulary>to get thin</vocabulary>, just join the <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (や). They run their players around those four bases so much they all get thin quicker than you can throw a ball.

examples.en: I heard the beauty salon specializes in slimming.
examples.ja: そのエステは痩身を専門にしているんだって。

examples.en: I kept getting massages for about a year, but I didn't have any slimming results.
examples.ja: 一年くらいマッサージに通ったんだけど、痩身の効果はなかったよ。

examples.en: The person caught by the security camera was a slim guy.
examples.ja: 防犯カメラに写っていたのは、痩身の男性でした。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>thin</kanji> <kanji>body</kanji> type is called <vocabulary>lean</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>slim</vocabulary>. These days this is usually used in the context of <vocabulary>slimming</vocabulary> salons and massages you can get that may or may not work.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

examples.en: There is a star-shaped mole on Koichi's crotch.
examples.ja: コウイチの股には星の形のホクロがある。

examples.en: I'm thinking of getting a Tofugu tattoo in my groin area.
examples.ja: 股の辺りにトーフグのタトゥーを入れようと思っているんだ。

examples.en: After I passed through the tunnel, there was a fork in the road.
examples.ja: トンネルを出ると、道が二股に分かれていた。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>crotch</kanji> and the vocabulary also means <vocabulary>crotch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>groin</vocabulary>.

Note that 股 is a little less specific than 股間, and can also be used for a <vocabulary>fork</vocabulary> in a road or path, which makes sense when you think about it, doesn't it?
reading_mnemonic:
You learned the on'yomi for this kanji, but like many kanji it takes the kun'yomi when used by itself. You haven't learned the kun'yomi yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You've spilled something on your <vocabulary>crotch</vocabulary> again, but your pants are so stained at this point that it doesn't even <reading>matter</reading> (また).

examples.en: Honey is good for coughs.
examples.ja: 咳にはハチミツがいいですよ。

examples.en: I'm going to go and buy cough syrup.
examples.ja: 咳止めシロップを買いに行ってきます。

examples.en: My cough is lingering.
examples.ja: 咳が長引いています。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Why don't we go to Kyoto to see the autumn leaves?
examples.ja: 京都に紅葉を見に行きませんか？

examples.en: The autumn foliage season for this year has begun.
examples.ja: 今年も紅葉シーズンが始まりましたね。

examples.en: The Japanese maple in my yard has not yet turned red.
examples.ja: うちの庭の紅葉の木はまだ紅葉してません。

examples.en: "<ja>紅葉の紅葉</ja>" is read "momiji no kōyō."
examples.ja: 「紅葉の紅葉」は「モミジのこうよう」って読むんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've got some <kanji>deep red</kanji> <kanji>leaves</kanji>. You'll usually see those during autumn, which makes this <vocabulary>autumn leaves</vocabulary>. Just <vocabulary>red leaves</vocabulary> is fine too, though.

Note that this refers not only to the leaves themselves, but also the process of them changing color, so this can also mean <vocabulary>leaves turning red</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. As you haven't learned this reading for 葉 yet, here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your favorite pastime during autumn is sitting there admiring the <vocabulary>autumn leaves</vocabulary> while eating some <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). There's no better combination than autumn leaves and yogurt.

Note that there's also an additional reading, もみじ, used to refer to the Japanese maple tree, or its leaves, but we'd like you to focus on こうよう for this one.

examples.en: Diving is prohibited in this pool.
examples.ja: このプールでは飛び込みは禁止されています。

examples.en: This is a fence to prevent people from jumping in.
examples.ja: これは飛び込み防止のためのフェンスです。

examples.en: Newcomers must do door-to-door sales every day.
examples.ja: 新人は毎日、飛び込み営業をしなくてはなりません。

meaning_mnemonic:
You’re doing a 飛ぶ and 込む at the same time, or you <kanji>jump</kanji> <kanji>into</kanji>, meaning you're <vocabulary>diving in</vocabulary>. Picture yourself standing somewhere up high, and then jumping to dive into a deep body of water.

Alternatively, this can also refer to doing something, or joining or going somewhere without an appointment, announcement, or prior registration, which is where the <vocabulary>dropping by</vocabulary> meaning comes in. For some use cases of this, check out our common word combinations and context sentences below!
reading_mnemonic: As long as you remember that we're combining the kun'yomi readings of the verbs and then turning them into a noun, you should know how to read this.

examples.en: I bought a tenugui towel in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本で手拭いを買ってきました。

examples.en: How is a tenugui towel different from a regular towel?
examples.ja: 手拭いは、ふつうのタオルとどう違うんですか？

examples.en: Wow, cool! I didn't know there were WaniKani tenugui towels.
examples.ja: うわぁ、かっこいい！ワニカニの手拭いがあるなんて知らなかったです。

meaning_mnemonic:
You have the kanji for <kanji>hand</kanji> and the noun version of the verb for <kanji>wipe</kanji>. With a bit of imagination, that makes this a <vocabulary>hand towel</vocabulary>, or just a <vocabulary>towel</vocabulary>. They're a very specific kind of cloth towel, which is why you'll also often encounter them with their Japanese name <vocabulary>tenugui</vocabulary>.

Unlike お手拭き, which you learned about a few levels ago, 手拭い are always towels — never tissues. These thin, flat cloths are long and narrow, serving a variety of purposes beyond simply cleaning your hands. Their history is fascinating, so be sure to look them up!
reading_mnemonic: You have a standalone vocab (手) combined with the noun version of a verb (拭い from 拭う), which means that this uses kun'yomi readings. You've already learned these, so you should be good to go!
